ygData.subject: Re: Integrating RDF and REST
ygData.msgSnippet: Is anybody really interested in URIs that s you can t dereference? And also, I d like to point out that you can dereference URNs... various protocols do exist

Is anybody really interested in URIs that's you can't dereference? And
also, I'd like to point out that you can dereference URNs... various
protocols do exist and are in use to do that. 

I know the problem I'm trying to solve is this: given a set of of HTTP
resources, how can orthogonal 'metadata' that real clients don't care
about be associated with the resources in a clean, simple manner that
doesn't involve radical alterations to the pre-existing web.

- itdp

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, dave.cantrell@g... wrote:
> >A URI, even an HTTP URI, that cannot be dereferenced nonetheless 
> >provides a unique name for an abstract resource that can be 
> >distinguished from all other names for resources.
> 
> Yes, believe me I do get that point. :)
> 
> Maybe I can re-phrase this somehow...
> 
> REST is an architectural style for referencing resources across
HTTP, right?
> So then, what good does "urn:i-am-foo" do me when I can't (a) GET
it, (b)
> POST to it, (c) PUT it, or (d) DELETE it? How do these URIs fit into the
> scope of REST?
> 
> Or are we talking about two different things? I can see their use in
RDF (as
> mentioned in the original e-mail) as unique identifiers, but not as a
> REST/HTTP resource itself.
> 
> Hmm... Maybe I'm missing something here?
> 
> Thanks,
> -dave
